bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 14, 1948

div1.p: Kean discusses the career of McCoy. He answers Hench's questions from a previous letter. According to Kean, Gorgas initially rejected Reed's mosquito theory.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 14, 1948

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
Washington 7, D. C.
14 Jan '48

div1.p:
Your letter of 9 Jan. arrived
this afternoon and I was much inter-
ested in it- I will number your questions
in my reply to them by the same numbers-
1. Major Gen Frank R. McCoy, long since retired,
is (thank God) still living and is in Wash-
ington at 1633, 31st Street n. w. I have his
Christmas Card before me now, and he
called up by phone a few days ago to wish
me a happy New Year- He is a very able &
distinguished man- The President appointed him
to be the Chief of the Commission that tried
and condemned the men that were landed
on our shores from U-Boats during the war
2
by the Nazis to commit sabotage on our
military activities- He was for years at
the head of the magazine Foreign Affairs-
I have known him since he was a 2nd
Lieutenant, wounded at Santiago in the
Spanish War- I have never heard of the
statement you quote from Hagedorn's
Biography of Gen. Wood, but I was dis-
trustful of Hagedorn when he wrote his book-
But whatever Gen McCoy tells you is the
best available evidence- He was for years
the aide to Gen. Wood and then President
Theodore Rooseveld took him to be his aide
and he has always been mixed up in great
affairs, as you will see in brief resumé in
Whos Who- You can rely on him- Cornelia
tells me she told you two years ago to consult him-
1. As to this I doubt it
2. I doubt this also, but it may be true-

I never heard of Eric Fisher Wood's book:
“Leonard Wood” see p. 3-
3-
under 2. Wood did not appoint Gorgas
to be Chief San. Officer of Havana-
Gorgas was appointed Jan 13. 1899-
Gen. Wood did not come to Havana
as Gov. Gen. until Dec. 20. 1899-
Gorgas did not beleive in the mosquito
theory even after Reed had demonstrated
it- He told me, and he candidly put it
in his annual Report that he believed
Reed's demonstration “showed that it could be
conveyed by the mosquito but he did not
believe that it was the only way or even
the usual way-” He ignored the experiments
with fomites- But when Gen. Wood
ordered him to get to work on mosquito
prevention, the success of his own work
convinced him-

If it was a suggestion from Gen Wood which
decided Gen. Sternberg to appoint Reeds'
Board, McCoy will probably know about
it-
4.
I seen to have skipped this page so see
over for page 3-

Write to Gen McCoy by all means-
Shall I send him your letter to me?
Thanks for your stamped and
addressed envelopes, but you
need not have sent them- What
is a 3¢ stamp between me and three?
I am glad that you are going to
England in the SpringAutumn- The rest of
the voyage will do you good, so do
not go by air, which is quick but
not restful-

We had a hell of a time at Christmas
Both ill with Virus Influenza-
But we are both well now, tho-
Cornelia was ill 3 weeks during which
time she saw no one- Hoping that you
and your family will escape it we wish
you all a happy and healthy New Year
